displayed_text: Patient: Thank you. (laughs) Doctor: Um but that’s an option where… Patient: I’m working on year seventy-four so I’m hanging in there. Doctor: Doing pretty darn good. Um but I think the the downside of that trial is you’re here all the time, but the plus side is you’re getting you know the chemo is a standard and the vitamin C we’ll see what happens so. Patient: Yeah. If I need to cancel that trip… Doctor: Okay. Patient: …to S___, it’s a done deal. Doctor: Okay - No. N - honestly you gotta get off Casodex for six weeks anyways… Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: …so the timing is perfect. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Why I wanted you in here is one, we have a plan in place…

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 10 years (5 years but le: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 10 years (5 years but less than 10 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::strongly agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.strongly disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Prefer to self-describe (please specify): What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Prefer to self-describe (please specify)

Please feel free to leave any comments a.text_box: Thank you for the opportunity to participate!

displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright? Patient: That’s good. That’s good. I’m going to keep the faith that everything is, is good. Doctor: Okay. Now very good. (pause7sec) Patient: I try not to worry. You know? Doctor: Yeah. Don’t worry. Patient: Worry. You know? Because that, that’s, that’s bad. Doctor: That’s very bad. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Yes. You don’t want to do that. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Stress can cause a lot of problems with the rest, other parts of the body.

Family Member: Okay. Alright. Yeah. Alright. Doctor: So. Uh. So, I just wrote a quick note to you that sort of says your options for your prostate cancer that is getting worse and that’s why PSA and more disease on bone scan. Okay? That’s how I made that decision. You can go with cabazitaxel chemotherapy, supportive care only. That will just keep you comfortable. Or, a clinical trial, ‘cuz again with cabazitaxel, you’re gonna get supportive care. With clinical trial, you’re gonna get supportive care. You know, we’re always here to make sure you – we keep you comfortable. Uh. The clinical trial, you would need to start the enzalutamide, then have a rising PSA Patient: Yep. Doctor: It could be as short as three weeks from now that everything works. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Okay? But again, the logistics of getting the drug, the logistics of you taking it, logistics of getting a PSA, then you coming back down here and get an ARV seven and then having a week for it to come back, it’s . Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um. I’m gonna put the prescription for the enzalutamide in our pharmacy, and they’re gonna do all the work behind the scenes to find out how much it’s gonna cost ya. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Put in the grants and all that other stuff for ya, so that we can get it. Once we know it’s a go, that’s when R_ and I will be back in touch about that. Okay? But you can always back out and say, “This doesn’t make sense. I’m not ready. He’s crazy. We’re not going back to Baltimore.” All of that. Okay? Something bad could happen. You could get in a lot of pain, and they got to treat you right then and there, and this will, will slip past you. Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But I hope that doesn’t happen. Patient: And even, even this treatment – is successful or just extend me for –

Patient: No. It won’t be a couple of months. We couldn’t handle a couple of months. Doctor: Okay. We’ll shoot for less than a month. How about that? Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Okay. How you doing on the XTANDI? Not too bad? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay. You look great. But anything compared to last time when you weren’t feeling so hot and your blood sugar was…… YOU LOOK GREAT! (Laughs) Patient: Well, I feel good. Doctor: Okay. We’ll have to see what your PSA is but obviously last time it’s gone down, and I’m thrilled. Patient: Well, let’s hope it’s gone down. So we haven’t gotten it back? Doctor: Um hum. Not from today but we’ll call ya’. Family Member: Oh yeah. I need to give the nurse the new phone number. Doctor: Oh. Well holler to him. He’ll write it and pass it on to K___ too just in case.

Patient: Okay. Um, okay well I follow your advice. Family Member: Can I ask a couple questions? Patient: Yes you can. Family Member: Now I can ask? Patient: Now you can talk. Family Member: So do you have any experience with the BET inhibitor? Have you seen it work or is it so new that you don’t really know? Doctor: I have experience with a different BET inhibitor. So not this particular one. (Coughs) Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: -was an injection type of BET inhibitor. This one is a pill. So I think uh, no I really don’t have too much experience with this particular one. The study just opened frankly – Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: -- and now we have two or three people who will probably start right around the same time. Family Member: Mm, hmm.

Patient: No. You’ve got it all. Doctor: So I’m going to put Bell’s palsy on here. You said it’s lopsided? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And you’ve had, not had any issues with depression in the past or anxiety? Patient: No. Doctor: Any acid reflux? Patient: Uh-uh. Doctor: Ever have a seizure? Patient: No. Doctor: Stroke? Patient: Nope. Doctor: Sleep apnea?

Patient: What happened to the radiation that I took for the forty some days? Whatever did that do any good or it did nothing or what? Doctor: Well, I think it’s controlling your local, you know. Patient: You think it made a difference? Okay. Doctor: Oh, yeah. Oh, I think so. Yeah, those aren’t the problem cells. Those guys are dumb and dead. It’s the smarter ones that are like party. They may have not been even in the field of radiation. They may have already been floating around. So, just to also make sure we talk about the genetics stuff that you did because the biopsy didn’t really yield anything… Patient: Right, okay, that’s one of the things. Doctor: Yeah, right, it kind of all went south after that but we did check your blood. If you remember we sent a couple of tubes to a company called Guardian Health Patient: Yes. Doctor: and that almost yielded nothing either. You had like one abnormality at zero point one percent as in I don’t think you have much floating around which is kind of good but nothing that we can sort of target. Patient: Yeah, Okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So, we got a target something? Doctor: Well, I think we… Patient: Got to find out if we…

Patient: For how long? Doctor: Well that’s what the consent will give you the exact details Patient: Okay, Yeah. Doctor: of how many times a week, but the first few weeks typically are very, what this is called is a Phase I study. So it’s an earlier setting like I said the combination really we don’t have a good handle on what to expect in terms of toxicities, what dose, etc. So one of the side effects that has been noted so far is that the platelets can drop with this medication. So that is something of course the blood counts will be monitored anyway. Besides that kidney function, liver function, all that will also be monitored and checked. You go – undergo EKG monitoring that will be hard test like and echo before you start. So there is a lot of components. One additional component is that you probably will need to do a biopsy again as part of the study. Doctor: So that’s something to think about before you say yes or no. Patient: And does platelets dropping how would that affect me physically? Doctor: Well if it gets really low then it can cause bleeding and things like that - Family Member: Like internal? Doctor: -but the whole idea of this closed monitoring is to not let it get that far. But you know obviously if you notice any bleeding, nose bleeds, gum bleeds, blood in the urine, whatever I need to know right away. Family Member: But how about the bleeding that’s rectal bleeding that he’s having now. Doctor: Yeah, yeah, so has you know we’ll probably have to wait and see, but changes are that should respond to just medical management and will clear up. Family Member: Yeah and you know we had the colonoscopy and the… Doctor: Yeah

Patient: I don’t think that did anything for me. Doctor: Right, yeah, yeah. Patient: And so after a couple of months, he said, “This isn’t working,- Doctor: Yes. Patient: -so let’s not continue it.” Doctor: Right. You know the good part is there’s always new stuff coming down the pike. Patient: There is. Doctor: And we’ve just got to keep you upright and functioning and enjoying life- Patient: Right Doctor: -and keep those options open. Patient: But the other thing, I mean this is kind of the other side of what you have to deal with- Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: Oh the shoulders are good. Doctor: Okay what is…? Patient: I don’t have any you know… Doctor: Is this ten mg? Patient: Five in the morning, five at night. Doctor: Okay did it flare up after the treatment last time? Family Member: No. Patient: No. Doctor: You didn’t notice any different? Doctor: Okay so should we try going to five once a day or you don’t want to rock the boat? Patient: I suppose we could try it and see what happens. Doctor: We’re gonna try it. Family Member: Or even five one day and two the next and five one day and two the next.

Patient: Also, some neurologist thing, you know, but, syncope. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: He told me to start weaning off from the tamoxifen. Patient: And that stuff is nasty to get off from. Doctor: Go slow. Patient: Yeah. That’s right. So I don’t know if that’s going to effect- Doctor: Sure. What we will- the nice part about this, is you sign up for what you can do. The minute it doesn’t go right, then we just stop. That’s the good part. That’s the really good part. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay. During the- this is different than the Lupron and that right? Isn’t this usually used for gastric? Doctor: It’s all, yeah, but there’s a lot of information for earlier states like now. So it’s also been given in men right before their surgery stages. We know that the cancer cells are dying in the actual prostate. So it’s been given in every possible place, but the FDA approval is when you’re castrate resistant. Yeah. Patient: Okay. That’s what I read. Doctor: I know. Man. What happened here? Did you teach him stuff? Family Member: I didn’t, actually.

Healthcare Professional: Sorry, excuse me. Doctor: So um…just want to go over what's going on and sort of your scan results. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Let me ask first what your questions are. And then I can give you some thoughts. Patient: My question would be what are your thoughts about it? I mean, when you and I talked, we were kind of like, well, let's take the scans and see what comes up. We didn't necessarily think anything would because it's so small the numbers that we're reading right now. Doctor: Yeah, I still believe that. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: My sense is that this really was a new baseline just to make sure we're, you know, again, it's unusual for this to be real. Patient: Right. Doctor: But it's a possibility. I mean I just had a patient just before you his PSA was point three, something showed up, we put a biopsy and guess what it was prostate cancer- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -but that's not the norm. It doesn't make sense. And yet that's an example where it shows possibility.

Patient: If your choice is to have the weight on there or to be a memory I guess I’ll take the weight and work with that. Patient: How have you been? Doctor: Okay. Just running around. Giving more trials and you know keep going. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um I think you know you look great so we need to just come up with… Patient: I feel pretty good. Doctor: …you know whatever that end date is and it probably should have been your last infusion if we’re gonna.. Patient: It probably will be and I mean I Doctor: Yeah. Patient: think that the decision point, I see him a week from today. Doctor: Mhmm. Okay . Patient: And then he’ll have the um PSA number at that point in time.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Any other questions? Patient: No. Like I say the PSA thing is, of course you know we were always brought up with that kind of… Doctor: I know, I know. Patient: And you understand it. Doctor: No I absolutely… Patient: And I just wondered you know with. Doctor: Yes. Yeah I agree with you. Patient: As far as, as far as… Doctor: It’s not a trivial issue by any means. Patient: But you know like I say with the PSA if it’s up and everything but the scans the CT scans are good I mean if they’re… Doctor: Yeah, so that’s a good situation to be in is what I’ll tell you. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s folks who have like not so much hair at this age who just easily lose it. You have a lot of hair. Patient: Yes. When I was on the uh Cometriq. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: It started a little thinning but it was turning white. Doctor: Yeah. Um hum. Healthcare Professional: Um hum. Patient: And then we adjusted the dose and it started coming. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: So. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: I had to straighten this way.
